OATs: Better pricing, Reduced

What was an usually quiet summer EGB spreads (see EGBs while you were away) has already been interrupted by the news out of France. PM Bayrou has called a confidence vote for 8 September. With this procedure, the government needs more votes "in favour" than "against" to survive, which makes it more challenging that the previous motions of no confidence (initiated by opposition parties) that the current government survived in the recent past.
Our main thoughts around OATs and valuations:

1. We have had a structural bearish OAT & bullish BTP view for a while, motivated primarily by the improving external position of Italy and deteriorating external position of France, which was not reflected in relative valuations.  
2. In early March we temporarily closed our trade due to reasons related to the rising importance of defence for Europe, laid out in our piece In defence of OAT. In early summer, we re-initiated a BTP/OAT tightener as we were entering the period during which political risk could materialise.  
3. This political risk is now materialising and we have reached our target on the trade (10bp on BTP/OAT). Hence the emerging question is where do we go from here.  
4. From a valuation perspective, we reconfirmed recently that the external position is indeed empirically the best forward looking indicator with higher predictive power than Debt/GDP or credit ratings.  
5. OATs are now trading cheap not only on our Twin Deficit metric but on every other metric as well. France is finally pricing political risk.  
6. How far could it widen vs Bund? If we take last year as a reference, there are three important differences: i) RN is, at least in principle, becoming more fiscally conservative, ii) Defence is a greater market focus and iii) Germany is spending.  
7. On that basis, one could think that last year's widers, 80-85bp on 10yr OAT/Bund (using Bloomberg spline), should be a reasonable ceiling rather than a floor.  
8. On the Italian side, valuations remain favourable on all metrics except for Debt/GDP. But i) Debt/GDP has relatively weak forecasting power and ii) even vs Debt/GDP, Italy is only marginally expensive. In sharp contrast to France (and maybe Spain), there is no political risk on the horizon.

Conclusion: We maintain the BTP/OAT tightener, moving the target to flat and the stop to 15bp (on the Bloomberg spline). Should OAT/Bund reach the 80- 85bp range, we will consider switching our trade to a BTP/Bund tightener instead.

The 10yr OAT/Bund spread (using BBG splines) is currently at around 74bp (Figure 1). This compares to highs of 80- 85bp reached in Q4 2024 amid peak political uncertainty. However, when compared to other EGB spreads (Figure 2), OATs are cheaper today than they were at any point in the past.
Note: This note was originally published on 26 August 2025.
Figure 5: OAT/Bund residual vs TD model
Source : Deutsche Bank Research
Figure 6: Richness/cheapness vs Macro variables
Source : Deutsche Bank Research

Moreover, it's not just the Twin Deficit, OATs are trading cheap relative to all the Macro variables we've examined in our recent study as is shown in Figure 6. Nevertheless, it's worth flagging that the average residual of OATs is still below that of BTPs which trade cheaper than OATs on all macro variables except for Debt/GDP and credit ratings. However, these two are the ones with the weaker predictive power as our study showed.

France has already been downgraded by S&P in May 2024 and Moody's in December 2024. At the moment, it's rated AA- by all three main rating agencies, and is under a negative outlook by both Fitch & S&P. The next scheduled rating reviews are on 12 September by Fitch, 24 October by Moody's and 28 November by S&P. While losing the AA credit rating and move to single AA has no bond index eligibility implications or ECB eligibility problems, it's still considered as an important downgrade which could lead to outflows from real money investors. This is very difficult to quantify but it's important to keep in mind ahead of the upcoming rating reviews.

At the moment, OATs are already trading wider than what France's current credit rating would imply as is shown in Figure 7. The residual of 10y OAT ASW vs France's current credit rating is at around 30bp. This means that the market is already trading OATs as if having a 2- 3 notches lower credit rating. That's why most recent negative rating actions on France had a muted market impact.

This report summarises key macroeconomic metrics and frameworks that we are closely monitoring. We provide a regular update on the evolution of developed market (DM) rates markets in the recent past. Considering the uncertainty surrounding trade and fiscal policy, we begin by comparing budget balances and current account balances across major DM countries. We then analyse the distribution of outstanding bonds by investor type to assess the proportion held by price- insensitive investors, such as domestic central banks. Moving to market pricing, we examine pricing trends of major central banks, followed by recent market movements in key rates products. Finally, we update our cross- country PCA of term premia, as well as the seasonality of selected rates instruments. Definitions, methodologies, links to our key views, and recent publications are provided in the appendix.

Over the past month, contrary to the typical seasonal flattening trend, DB 5s10s term premia have risen across most G10 countries/regions, with the exceptions of Switzerland and New Zealand. This increase in term premia is also evident at the long end of the curve, as 2s30s slopes in most countries extended their steepening momentum through summer. As we head into autumn, seasonals until the end of October remain more favourable for higher term premia.

Considering potential twist- steepening in the US, coupled with seasonal and structural supply/demand drivers, we added a short 10y UST trade to our macro portfolio in August. Additionally, following recent political developments in France, we revised our BTP/OAT tighter trade's target to flat and stop to 15bp. We also introduced a new tariff- inflation map at the end of last month; please refer here for details.

Regarding current valuation, UST, JGB, and Swiss government bonds appear rich across most of our frameworks, while UKT, ACGB, and SGB look cheap across most metrics. Given rising concerns over debt sustainability in major G10 and European countries, we recently tested multiple macro variables' explanatory and predictive power. This analysis showed debt/GDP has weaker predictive power on future government bond performance, while residuals of mapping between yields and external position measures (e.g., current account, NIIP) exhibit better mean- reverting properties. For more details, please see our latest assessment across EGBs and G10.

Twin Deficit is simply the sum of the projected Budget & Current Account deficit of each country in the current year. Twin Deficit score is a synthetic weighted average where we assign a higher weight to this year's Twin Deficit (t), followed by gradually lowering the weights of the past five years (t-1, t-2,..., t-5) twin deficits and finally adding some weight to the cumulative Twin Deficit up to year t-5. This allows us to create a synthetic Twin Deficit score which combines both the most recent flow and the historical stock of budget & current account deficits.

Appendix A: Definition and methodologyTwin deficits and twin deficits score: Twin deficits are one of our preferred measures of fiscal policy space. In addition to the conventional twin deficit calculation, which is simply the sum of the projected Budget & Current Account deficit of each country data from the IMF's World Economic Outlook (WEO) database, we have also created a "twin deficits score". For each year, the twin deficits score is a weighted average of the previous years' twin deficits. We assign a higher weight to this year's Twin Deficit (t), followed by gradually lowering the weights of the past five years (t- 1, t- 2, ..., t- 5) twin deficits and finally adding some weight to the cumulative twin deficit up to year t- 5. This allows us to create a synthetic twin deficit score which combines both the most recent flows and the historical stock of budget & current account deficits. Considering the fundamental difference between Norway and other G10 countries, we make adjustments to Norway's twin surpluses and NIIP when mapping with its market pricing.

Net international investment positions (NIIP): NIIP is a measure of a country's reliance on foreign funding and, empirically, it is highly correlated with 10- year and 30- year government bond yields in cross- sectional regressions. Examining more recent movements, specifically those since Liberation Day, the NIIP can explain approximately \(80\%\) of the yield change. This framework offers a novel descriptive perspective for analysing rates markets amidst trade policy uncertainty, rather than serving as a fair value model for identifying trading opportunities. For countries without 30- year benchmark bonds, such as Sweden and Norway, we use SGB 2045 and NGB 2042 as proxies.

Free float: Historically, free float is highly correlated with DB term premium. We define free float as \(100\%\) minus the proportion of government bonds held by pricesensitive investors, such as domestic central banks, foreign official institutions, pension funds, and insurance companies. Due to limited data availability for Switzerland, Sweden, and Norway, we focus primarily on the remaining seven countries/regions.

FX hedged 10y and 30y yield vs USD: We estimate the 3- month hedging cost using 3- month forward points and prevailing spot exchange rates. These costs were then deducted from the unhedged benchmark bond yields. For countries without a 30- year benchmark bond, such as Sweden and Norway, we present the 20- year bond yield as an alternative.

Swap term premium vs 5y5y inflation swap: Empirically, inflation forward is a key driver of DB term premium (5s10s + 0.2\*2s). Consequently, we run a one- year rolling regression on weekly data to examine current term premium pricing is rich/ cheap.
Cross- market PCA: We conduct a 3m fixed window PCA on DB 5s10s cash term premium in this section.

Seasonality: We apply the same methodology in this publication to 5s10s term premium of cash and swaps, as well as 10- year swap spreads and 5y5y inflation swaps. Red indicates higher term premium/higher inflation/richer cash vs. swaps (i.e. higher (swaps- cash)). Due to data availability issues in certain instruments and markets, the calculation in this publication use the data after 2017 to make the results more comparable.

Carry and rolldown estimates: We use Bloomberg BVAL splines and 3m short- term rates to estimate carry and rolldown across countries. For countries without 30- year benchmark bonds, such as Sweden and Norway, we use the nearest available point on the spline curves. For Sweden, values in the 20- year and 30- year cells represent 15- year & 25- year bonds respectively. For Norway, values in the 20- year and 30- year cells represent 15- year& 20- year bonds respectively. The carry and rolldown for swap spreads is defined as long cash versus pay swaps.

Latest assumptions on RBA path: We no longer expect an RBA rate cut in September, but the RBA's dithering on policy easing in 2025 means more in 2026. Specifically, we think the RBA will now need to cut rates three more times, for a new terminal rate of \(2.85\%\) (previously \(3.1\%\) ). In terms of timing, we expect one more 25bp cut this year at the November meeting, and two more in early 2026: 25bps in February and 25bps in March. Last evening, President Trump announced the removal of Governor Cook from the Federal Reserve Board, citing "cause" due to alleged fraud in relation to mortgages she took out on properties before her appointment to the Board. This announcement was the culmination of intensifying pressure from the administration in recent days on this issue. In response, Governor Cook argued that "no cause exists under the law, and he [President Trump] has no authority to do so."

The announcement, and indications that Cook is set to challenge the decision, tees up a legal battle on whether the President can remove a Fed governor. As we have discussed previously, a recent Supreme Court ruling related to Humphrey's Executor determined that the President had the legal authority to remove heads of independent federal agencies but carved the Federal Reserve out of that decision, citing its unique historical institutional setup and the importance of independence related to monetary policy decisions. Despite this, Fed governors can still be removed for cause. The legal question here will be whether what the administration has alleged meets that legal burden.

At Jackson Hole, Chair Powell signalled his cautious support for a rate cut in September (see "Powell's speech at Jackson supports September action"). However, his speech also laid out reasons why the FOMC is unlikely to undertake a steep path of rate reductions over the coming meetings, at least under his leadership and current composition.

Following the resignation of Fed Governor Kugler earlier this month, Trump has growing support on the Committee for easier monetary policy. Governors Waller and Bowman - two Trump appointees who are also being considered for the chair position - dissented in favor of a rate cut at the July FOMC meeting and will likely continue to push for easing at upcoming meetings. Stephen Miran, who is currently chair of the Council of Economic Advisers and has been nominated to replace Kugler, is expected to add another dovish voice to the near- term policy debate (see "What Miran means for the race to replace Powell"). But as recent Fedpeak has demonstrated, this building dovish wing is likely to face meaningful resistance from a sizeable hawkish block of officials that do not support easing policy meaningfully, if at all.

How would replacing Cook impact this dynamic? We have viewed Cook as one of the most dovish officials on the Committee. Prior to the latest news, she expressed greater concerns around the labor market and appeared to lean towards supporting a near- term rate cut. As such, we do not anticipate a titanic shift to take place if Cook is in fact replaced. Nonetheless, with support for potentially steep rate cuts likely a prerequisite for candidates to replace Cook, another Trump appointee on the Board would add reliable voice for easier policy, even in the face of higher inflation that is to come. Indeed, the potential for four dissents from Governors - a majority of the Board - could intensify internal pressure for easier policy ahead.
Note: This note was originally published on 26 August 2025.
Beyond near- term monetary policy decisions, there are some potentially broader implications for the Federal Reserve and monetary policy from achieving a majority on the Federal Reserve Board.

First, the interest rate on reserve balances (IORB), is set by a majority vote of the Board, not the FOMC. Historically, the Board has set IORB at an appropriate level to maintain the fed funds rate within the target range set by the FOMC. But, theoretically at least, a Board with a majority that did not agree with the FOMC decision could set IORB at a different - in this case lower - level. If the goal is to achieve lower rates, and the FOMC is not supportive, one unprecedented way to do that would be through this channel. That said, there may be limits to the related impact, as the FOMC sets the ONRRP rate and could continue to do so with a goal of keeping overnight repo rates near its target range. That would create unprecedented dynamics in money markets but potentially mute the impact of lower IORB out the curve.

Second, in addition to approving new nominations for regional Fed bank presidents, every five years the presidents of the twelve regional banks come up for approval by the Board. This process is typically uncontentious and passes without notice, as the Board supports the leadership decisions of the regional Board of Directors of each bank. However, this need not continue to be the case. If the desire for lower rates met resistance from a more hawkish block of regional Fed presidents, a majority on the Board could take the unprecedented move of not approving some of the regional voters. Importantly, the next five- year approval is slated for Q1 next year.

This short list is unlikely to be exhaustive. There may be other avenues through which the administration could re- orient the Federal Reserve with a majority of the Board. At the very least, it is clear there are ways to influence the setting of monetary policy besides appointing doves to the Board of Governors.

As we argued in a recent note (see "Excess Fed easing and long- term yields"), there is evidence that sustained easier- than- warranted monetary policy has been followed by higher nominal 10y yields. This empirical observation fits with intuition and market positioning, that an overly accommodative Fed is likely to result in a twist- steepening of the curve. Threats to Fed independence are likely to lead to higher inflation expectations and inflation risk premia, and potentially make investors wary of owning longer- term Treasuries. This twist- steepening is in fact what occurred last evening and this morning in response to the news of Cook's removal. Our preference is to express this through lower front- end real yields versus higher long- end nominal yields (see "Summary of key US rates views").

That said, higher long- end yields clearly work against the administration's desire to push debt service costs lower. And as we argued previously, there is likely to be limited improvements in these costs unless there is a sustained sizeable move lower in yields across the curve (see "Removing Powell won't move the needle on Treasury debt costs"). We therefore see the administration's response as a potential material headwind to this view, namely how they decide to lean against higher long- end yields through debt management policy, financial regulation, and other tools.
Eurozone and UK Sovereign Issuance: 01st Sep - 05th Sep

Austria completed its syndication quota by launching the new 7- year benchmark, RAGB Sep- 32, for EUR 3.25 billion (see our H2 syndication expectations). Overall issuance for the week totaled EUR 21.6 billion (EUR 12.3 billion in 10- year equivalent terms). Looking ahead, September is anticipated to commence with significant supply in EGB primary markets, as scheduled issuance for next week is estimated at EUR 27.5 billion (EUR 20.9 billion in 10- year equivalent terms)

Germany will initiate the week's supply on Tuesday by issuing BKO Sep- 27 for EUR 4.5 billion, followed by an auction of DBR Aug- 35 for EUR 5.0 billion on Wednesday. Thursday will see Spain auctioning SPGB Jul- 28, Jul- 31, and Jan- 37 for an expected EUR 5.5- 6.0 billion, alongside SPGBei Nov- 30 for an estimated EUR 500 million. On the same day, France is expected to auction OAT May- 35, May- 42, and May- 56 for EUR 9.5- 11.0 billion. Belgium will conclude the week's supply on Friday by auctioning its off- the- run bonds via its ORI facility for an expected EUR 500 million. With no redemptions scheduled next week, net supply is anticipated to be positive.

In the UK, there will be a syndication of a new conventional gilt \(4.75\%\) Oct 2035 and auction of linker \(0.625\%\) Mar 2045 next week. In the following week, there will be an auction of \(4.75\%\) Oct 2043, \(4\%\) Oct 2031 and a tender sale of conventional gilt at the short end or linker. Gross gilt supply in the next two weeks should be \(\sim\) £18.7bn in cash terms and \(\sim\) £15.1mn/bp in DV01 terms. In terms of cash flow, with no gilt sales from the APF portfolio by the BoE and scheduled coupon payment to market in the next week, gilt net supply (supply - coupon to market + active QT) should be \(\sim\) £12.8mn/bp in DV01 terms for the next two weeks.

We summarize our key views, as published over this week:

Fixed Income Chart Of The Day: Inflation - tracking tariff effects (29 August 2025) Fixed Income Chart Of The Day: Another step- up in term premia (28 August 2025) Fixed Income Chart Of The Day: Excess Fed easing and long- term yields (26 August 2025)

One of the main uncertainties about the US inflation outlook is the magnitude and timing with which any tariff- related upward pressure materialises. As we argued in our bottom- up tariff- inflation mapping, historical evidence suggests that the direct effects from imported consumer goods will materialize relatively quickly. Building upon that analysis, today's CoTD looks at recent trends in the most tariff- sensitive subset of consumer prices.

We construct a PCE tariff- basket based on the share of direct import content for each item, including only those PCE goods categories with the highest direct import content for which tariffs increases have been implemented. The chart below shows that the 6m annualized change of the tariff- basket PCE index has accelerated to its highest level in 30 years in July, excluding the Covid period.

The pass- through from tariffs is unlikely to be complete and we expect further upward pressure on prices ahead. It is likely that the sharp rise in imports of consumer goods up to March this year means that a portion of sales continues to be out of pre- tariff inventories for now, firms may have opted to initially tighten margins, which could revert over time and further tariff increases on goods such as pharmaceuticals or semi- conductors seem likely. Meanwhile, business surveys and PPI trends suggest that indirect effects will add to the upward pressures over time. We continue to see core inflation accelerate towards \(3.5\%\) y/y early next year, and that is one of the factors underpinning our short 10y UST view.
Figure 140: Tariff-sensitive inflation has accelerated to the highest level in 30y (ex Covid)
Source:Deutsche Bank,Haver Analytics, BEA

Another step- up in term premiaThe DB term premium (5s10s steepener with a beta hedge of \(20\%\) short in 2s) has risen by \(\sim 60\) bp since we laid out the argument for a structural increase more than 3 years ago. It has reached the recent peak observed in October 2023 and is not far from the assumption behind our current 2025 rates forecast. There are tactical and strategic arguments for expecting another step- up.

From a tactical perspective, the coming two months tend to be favourable to higher term premia. From a strategic perspective, several key factors justify a further increase in term premia. Firstly, the shift in supply/demand summarised by our global free float continues to point to upside, which is further supported by the fiscal stance at the global level. Secondly, the risks to Fed independence support a higher risk premium. Thirdly, China seems to have opted for a (gradual) focus on domestic demand rather than further support to exports by implementing "anti- involution" measures and allowing its currency to appreciate. Fourthly, after all, the term premium is still at its pre- 2014 historical low, and the conditions that led to a low term premium environment in the 2014- 2020 period (relatively tight fiscal policy, positive supply shock to oil prices, central bank QE) are reversed (structurally easier fiscal policy, negative supply shocks, central bank QT, immigration controls and tariffs).

The main risks to this view would come from (1) US tariff revenues exceeding expectations enough to generate a material fiscal tightening, (2) Al exerting significant disinflationary pressures, and (3) OPEC+'s attempt to regain market share resulting in a significant decline in oil prices comparable to what was observed in 2014.
Figure 141: Another step-up in term premia
Source:Deutsche Bank Research,Bloomberg Finance LP
Note: This report was originally published on 28 August 2025.
Last night, President Trump announced that he is removing Federal Reserve Board Governor Cook from office.
This will likely intensify focus in US rates markets on how political pressure on the Fed could result in easier monetary policy than is warranted by fundamentals.

Our COTD last week looked at current and historical Fed rate policy against a set of monetary policy rules. We found that the Fed is currently well positioned and, with conservative neutral- rate estimates, 25bp of easing could be warranted.

Since then, Chair Powell at Jackson Hole signaled an upcoming cut and markets are now grappling with the news on Cook on top of other intensifying pressures on the Fed. We see increasing signs the market is pricing easier policy under the next chair - an OIS premium next June and shifting front- end real rate dynamics.
All of this raises an obvious question: what have deviations of Fed policy from standard policy rules meant for US rates historically?

Today's chart shows the relationship to 10y UST using the measure of "excess tightness" implied by our chart last week: the difference between the fed funds target and the median rate from a set of standard monetary policy rules. We see clear evidence that sustained easier- than- warranted policy has historically been followed by higher nominal 10y yields, though the effects unfold over years not quarters, and it really boils down to two episodes: the Great Inflation of the 1970s and Covid. Based on the scatter best- fit line, if the Fed were to pursue policy that is 1.5ppt easier than called for by the median rule, 10y UST should be around 50bp higher than otherwise over coming years.

This supports our recent short 10y UST (target of \(4.6\%\) ). And it reinforces our view that the clearest expression in rates of a politicized Fed is in higher long- end rates, twist- steepeners (especially with front- end reals) and higher CPI swaps. But a key risk to each of these is that the administration could lean against a material rise in long- term rates using debt management policy, financial regulation and, in the extreme, the Fed's balance sheet. Even the possibility of these could cap upward pressure on the long end.
Figure 142: Deviations of Fed policy from policy rules have foreshadowed future yield moves

We provide an overview of NGEU RRF disbursements so far (Figure 143- Figure 148). The EU disbursed EUR 23.3bn of grants and EUR 32.6bn of loans making it a total of EUR 55.8bn under RRF ytd. Of this EUR 55.8bn, EUR 44.9bn has come in Q3 so far making it the third highest quarter already since the start of the program since Q3 2021. In terms of countries receiving the loans in Q3 2025, Spain received the highest loan of EUR 15.9bn followed by Italy which received loan of EUR 13.6bn. In terms of grants in Q3 2025, Spain received highest grants for EUR 7.1bn followed by Italy (EUR 4.6bn) and Sweden (EUR 1.6bn).

Since the start of the program, annual disbursements in loans have lagged the annual disbursements in grants. However, ytd disbursements of loans have exceeded the grants by EUR 9.3bn so far. Total grant and loan disbursements under RRF amount to EUR 220.7bn and EUR 141.3bn so far, respectively, leading to a total of EUR 362bn. Italy has been the biggest beneficiary of loans and Spain has been the biggest beneficiary of grants in total in all years since 2021.

Average monthly RRF disbursements of grant and loans since the beginning of August 2021 amount to EUR 4.5bn and EUR 2.88bn, respectively. There are 16 months remaining until Dec 2026. Hence, assuming the same pace, RRF disbursements would amount to only EUR 72.1bn in grants and EUR 46.1bn in loans and therefore EUR 118.2bn in total by the end of 2026.

Given that the total volume of RRF grants and loans is planned to amount to EUR 655.8bn, with only EUR 362bn (55.2%) disbursed so far, our calculation suggests that RRF disbursements need to speed up significantly to get the planned RRF volume completed by the end of 2026. With EUR 293.8bn of disbursements planned for remainder of 2025 and 2026, the amount that needs to be disbursed proportionately amounts to EUR 73.5bn over the remainder of 2025 and EUR 220.4bn in 2026, which is significant.

Extending the borrowing authorization for the EC requires a unanimous decision by EU Member States (MS) and we continue to assume that MS will ultimately use all allocated RRF funds. Thus, in our view, EU bond supply will remain high despite low RRF disbursements, likely amounting to the estimated EUR 155.8bn in 2025 and "around EUR 160bn" in 2026 (despite already high cash holdings at the EC).

Amid increasing concerns regarding French sovereign credit quality, EU bonds widened. Besides concerns about France, ICE not including the EU in its sovereign indexes and the resumption of supply (auction on Monday and the next syndication on 9 Sept) seem to weigh on spreads.

We provide the yield spread of 2y, 5y, 10y and 10y EU versus EGBs, KfW, EIB and CADES (2y and 5y) as of 25 Aug and the six months and one week change (Figure 157 - Figure 159), based on Bloomberg constant- maturity indices. The charts show that in 10y and 30y, the EU mainly underperformed versus EGBs, KfW and EIB in the

last one week. However, the EU outperformed 10y and 30y French sovereign bonds (OAT) on the last one week. In the event French sovereign bonds widen further, we expect the EU to further outperform France but to underperform Bunds.

Given the vote of confidence to be held in France on 8 Sept and elevated high sovereign debt levels already, we think further sovereign rating downgrades cannot be excluded. Regarding the rating agency review dates for France - Fitch will start on 12 Sept, DBRS will follow on 19 Sept, Moody's on 24 Oct, and S&P on 28 Nov. We do not expect a downgrade of the EU in the event of a downgrade of France by one of the large rating agencies, at least not in the near future.

Below is what Fitch stated in the latest rating report regarding factors that could lead to a downgrade: "Weaker Debt Coverage: An actual or projected decline in the additional contributions from 'AAA' rated MS below the level that fully covers annual debt service. This could result from the downgrade of one of the largest 'AAA' rated MS (such as Germany; accounting for 25% of EU27 GNI- based contributions for the EU's 2025 budget; or the Netherlands; 6%). Weaker Support: Weakening of our assessment of highly rated EU countries' propensity to support that affects our expectation of future EU contributions, and in an emergency situation, 'AAA' rated MS' willingness to provide additional funding could lead to a downgrade. Higher Guarantee Calls: Crystallisation of a material level of contingent liabilities via calls on the guarantee portfolio that threatens the maintenance of a positive 'free margin' between the total additional contributions from 'AAA' rated MS and the EU's annual debt service obligations." In our view, this does not suggest that the EU will be downgraded by Fitch in the event of a one- notch downgrade of France by Fitch.

Moody's stated in its latest rating report on the EU that "downgrade pressure could result from a further deterioration in the creditworthiness of highly rated EU members that are large contributors to the EU budget, such as Germany (Aaa stable) or France (Aa3 stable). That said, the EU's Aaa rating also has a degree of resilience to such downward rating changes. Any potential weakening in the commitment of highly rated member states to support the EU financially would put the Aaa rating in jeopardy; unilateral national reductions in budget contributions could constitute such a signal. The joint and several nature of the obligations of member countries relative to EU obligations has never been tested. Should anything occur which suggests that this feature is weaker than we previously expected, that would exert downward pressure on the rating. Downward pressure would also emerge if the EU's access to and quality of funding were to deteriorate significantly." While Moody's suggests a quasi- direct link between the rating of the EU and the rating of France, it also mentioned "a degree of resilience to such downward rating changes". In our view, given that the rating of France is still on outlook stable at Moody's and the "degree of resilience" mentioned by Moody's, we do not expect a downgrade of the EU in the event of a one- notch downgrade of France by Moody's, at least not in the near future.

S&P highlighted in its latest rating comment on the EU: "We could downgrade the EU if additional resources from highly rated member states (that is, those rated 'AA+' or higher, equivalent to two notches above the EU's 'aa-' anchor) were insufficient to cover the EU's debt service by more than 1x. We could also downgrade the EU if we observed declining political cohesion among EU member states, for example if the proposal by the European Commission to introduce new EU revenue sources was blocked beyond 2028 without identifying alternative sources. Although unlikely, we

could also lower our ratings on the EU if the nominal GDP-weighted average sovereign foreign currency rating on member states deteriorated significantly. While the wording by S&P suggests some uncertainty, we do not expect a downgrade of the EU by S&P in the event of a one-notch downgrade of France by S&P, at least not in the near future.

DBRS highlighted in its latest rating comment on the EU: "The EU's ratings could be downgraded if one or a combination of the following occurs: (1) a marked deterioration in the creditworthiness of a single core shareholder, particularly if it reflects a material weakening in the cohesion of core member states or of the strength of their political commitment to the EU; (2) a rise in anti-EU sentiment due to a lack of cohesion that ultimately results in a material increase in the risk of the EU's dissolution; or (3) although unlikely given its Stable trend, a downgrade of Germany (AAA, Stable)." In our view, this suggests that the EU will not be downgraded by in the event of a one-notch downgrade of France by DBRS.

EUR SSA supply to likely to increase 2026Our outlook for European SSA will be published at end of Nov. However, ESM/EFSF already indicate in the investor presentation that combined supply will decline to EUR 25bn (EUR 18bn EFSF, EUR 7bn ESM) in 2026 versus EUR 28.5bn in 2025 (EUR 21.5bn EFSF, EUR 7bn ESM). The EU Commission (EC) indicates that it will issue "around EUR 160bn" in 2026 (the same as in 2025). Given high cash holdings, low RRF disbursements so far and SAFE loan disbursements unlikely to be significantly front- loaded, we see more downside risk than upside risk regarding the "around EUR 160bn". EIB's operational plan for 2025- 2027 suggests an unchanged funding programme for 2026 (i.e. around EUR 60bn, probably with a borrowing authorisation of EUR 65bn). However, given ongoing political efforts to increasingly use EIB for various political goals, it seems fair to assume that there is more upside than downside risk.

The EUR 70bn estimated for KfW in 2025 is significantly lower than the EUR 78.1bn, EUR 90.2bn, EUR 89.4bn and EUR 82.6bn actually issued in 2024, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively. Supported by likely higher GDP growth and the government eager to support to economy, we expect supply by KfW to increase in 2026, probably to around EUR 80bn. In the case of Rentenbank, we expect supply to remain broadly unchanged at around EUR 10bn. While we do not have estimates for UNEDIC yet, with redemptions to increase in the case of UNEDIC to EUR 6.25bn in 2026 versus EUR 3bn in 2025 and UNEDIC itself forecasts a small financial deficit of EUR 0.4bn for 2026 versus EUR 0.3bn for 2025, supply is at least unlikely to decline versus the EUR 4bn for 2025.

There is significant uncertainty regarding supply by German federal states due to EUR 100bn they receive from the government infrastructure package. However, in our view, given ongoing pressure on budgets due to cost inflation, increasing staff and ongoing high costs for social welfare and immigration, we expect supply to increase further in 2026 versus the at least EUR 67bn we expect for 2025. Moreover, given the increasing pressure on federal state budgets, particularly smaller federal states could also try to increasingly use their respective promotional banks to support the economy, at least this is unlikely to decline.

Overall, while only very few issuers already provide funding indications for 2026 and supply in 2025 will likely end at a new historical high already, a further increase seems likely. Moreover, typically ongoing or even increasing deficits by sub- sovereign entities in Europe in general should support supply by European SSA in 2026. In line with this, according to a survey by LBBW among 57 issuers (65% financials, 35% SSA) and 202 investors, 80% of these issuers and 70% of these investors expect SSA supply to increase in 2026.

In our view, given our constructive broader market outlook until year- end and confirmed by last week's strong primary market demand, Australian (Canadian and UK) CB are attractive at current levels. Much better government budget and sovereign debt data of Australia compared to most European countries is an additional argument, particularly for investors willing to diversify away from highly indebted sovereigns with ongoing high budget deficits. Moreover, in our understanding, Australian banks are mainly done or at least ahead of their FY 2025 funding plans.

Australian (Canadian and UK) CB underperformed versus German Pfandbriefe in recent weeks and are therefore more attractive currently. Given likely low net supply of EUR benchmark CB until year- end, the spread could tighten back to the levels seen early July (before Australian, Canadian and UK CB underperformed). However, on a longer- term basis, Australian (Canadian and UK) CB are not necessarily very attractive versus German Pfandbriefe (Figure 160- Figure 162, based on 5y Bloomberg constant maturity indices).
Figure 160: Yield of 5y Bloomberg constant maturity Australian CB minus yield of 5y Bloomberg constant maturity German Pfandbriefe since 2010
Source : Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank
Figure 161: Yield of 5y Bloomberg constant maturity Canadian CB minus yield of 5y Bloomberg constant maturity German Pfandbriefe since 2010
Source:Bloomberg Finance LP,Deutsche Bank

One could argue that upcoming "third country equivalence" (i.e. Australian, Canadian and UK CB potentially becoming eligible for LCR level 1 and a \(10\%\) risk weighted in the EU) will support spreads of third country CB versus EEA CB. However, the relevant EBA report remains unpublished, and the EU Commission's current priorities likely lie elsewhere. Therefore, "third country equivalence" is unlikely to be implemented before 2027, if any. Furthermore, the yield premium observed on third country covered bonds versus Pfandbriefe during the COVID- 19 pandemic suggests that investors anticipating a broader market shock (a view contrary to our constructive outlook on the broader market) should exercise caution at current spread levels.

In case of Australian CB, there is one specific point versus, for example, Canadian and UK CB, justifying the need for an additional yield pick- up, which is the lack of ECB repo eligibility. Given that this is due to country of origin (i.e. Australia not being a G10/11 country), this is unlikely to change any time soon. The lack of ECB repo eligibility was very likely a the reason for the \(26\%\) share of banks/financial institutions in the 5y Australian EUR benchmark CB priced last week versus an average of around \(43\%\) in all EUR benchmark CB ytd. However, the very high order book and the \(34\%\) shares of fund managers, \(30\%\) central banks/0), \(8\%\) pension funds/insurance and others \(2\%\) still showed a very strong investor base despite lack of ECB repo eligibility.

Broadly line with a EUR 1bn 8y Green French CB priced at ms+45bp last Wednesday trading over 20bp tighter than French sovereign bonds at the end of week, 5y Bloomberg constant maturity French CB tightened further to a new historical tight versus 5y constant maturity French sovereign bonds (Figure 163).
French CB still look ok versus Pfandbriefe on a 5y and 10y history basis and the yield pick- up seen in 2011/12 is probably not the best reference (Figure 164). However,

given the historically tight spreads of French CB versus French sovereign bonds currently, the pick- up of French CB versus German Pfandbriefe is not necessarily attractive currently. However, it is also fair to stay that from a pure CB perspective (e.g. bank and collateral credit quality, OC and rating buffers), the yield pick- up versus Pfandbriefe is still decent.

Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.
